shared_text:
Brook Park Recreation Center
September 4 at 5:44 PM ·

With the 2020-2021 School Year quickly approaching and all the uncertainties it may bring to you and your families, we decided to dedicate our Brook Park Rec community message rock to all Titans Students, Teachers, and Staff for the entire month of September. We are encouraging positive messages to be written on the rock! You can stop in the Rec Center during normal business hours and we will provide you with a marker to write a message of encouragement and positive wishes in these challenging times while we all encounter Remote Learning together. Positive messages only please!
text:
Brook Park Recreation Center
September 4 at 5:44 PM ·

With the 2020-2021 School Year quickly approaching and all the uncertainties it may bring to you and your families, we decided to dedicate our Brook Park Rec community message rock to all Titans Students, Teachers, and Staff for the entire month of September. We are encouraging positive messages to be written on the rock! You can stop in the Rec Center during normal business hours and we will provide you with a marker to write a message of encouragement and positive wishes in these challenging times while we all encounter Remote Learning together. Positive messages only please!

post_text:
Congratulations to Superintendent Tracy Wheeler who was named a Superintendent to Watch by the National School Public Relations Association (NSPRA) for 2020!

Honorees are school district leaders who have fewer than five years of experience as a superintendent and who demonstrate dynamic, fast-paced leadership with strong communication at its core. They use communication technology in innovative and effective ways to engage and inform their school communities and to expand two-way communication and outreach efforts.

post_text:
The Free and Reduced Meal Application for the 2020-21 school year is now available.

Instructions:
1.) Go to www.mymealtime.com
2.) Click on the orange box that says "MealTime Apply Online" to start the application.
3.) You will need your student's ID number to complete the application.

You will receive an approval or denial letter within a week of returning your completed and signed application.

Questions, please call the Supervisor of Nutrition Services, Briana Cates at 216-267-2142 or email at bcates@bereaschools.org.

post_text:
Here are some of our newest 8th grade WEB Leaders!

WEB stands for Where Everybody Belongs. What does a WEB Leader do? WEB Leaders are 8th graders trained to work with the incoming 5th grade class and other new students who are entering middle school. The more contact a 5th grader has with their WEB Leader, the more successful the 5th grader will be!

#BeATitanTOGETHER #boomboom 💥💥

post_text:
Another student has been selected to serve on Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost's 2020-2021 Teen Ambassador Board. Congratulations to Madison Thomas!

The Teen Ambassador Board is an opportunity for Madison (BMHS junior) to meet students from across Ohio who are interested in law and government, and work with them to solve problems and provide suggestions to the Attorney General's office on vital issues facing our great state. Madison will have the opportunity to learn about the Attorney General’s office, meet and interact with government officials, work in groups on key initiatives, and discuss issues of importance to Ohio citizens.

FOX8.COM
Students say a final farewell to Berea-Midpark High School
text:
FOX8.COM
Students say a final farewell to Berea-Midpark High School

post_text:
Whether you are a Titan, a Brave, or even a Meteor, we know there are many fond memories that exist among these bricks and walls. You will always remember what was most personally important to you during your time in this building.

Even though time was cut short for the final graduating class of this school building, we can all learn from the Class of 2020. The memories you really treasure from high school may come from unexpected places, and some of the best memories won’t be formed during traditional events. You never know which experiences will shape, inspire, or affect you in retrospect. For some experiences, it will take years to see how truly special they were.

It was wonderful to see so many of you walk the halls of your high school, reflect upon your formative years, reminisce about your cherished friendships, and say your farewell today.

You never know which experiences will shape, inspire, or affect you in retrospect. For some experiences, it will take years to see how truly special they were.

It was wonderful to see so many of you walk the halls of your high school, reflect upon your formative years, reminisce about your cherished friendships, and say your farewell today.

post_text:
The Ohio Educational Library Media Association, Ohio’s preeminent professional association for highly effective school librarians and libraries, is pleased to announce that Katina Anagnostou, Library Media Specialist at Berea-Midpark Middle School is the recipient of the Rosen Publishing Ohio School Librarian of the Month Award.

The Rosen Publishing Ohio School Librarian of the Month recognizes one school librarian a month who designs, develops, and implements a collaborative lesson plan and/or programming that empowers student learning. This award spotlights the importance of both the school library community and librarian and the pivotal role each plays in transforming learning throughout students’ K-12 education.

Katina Anagnostou, as the recipient of this award, will have the opportunity to select and receive a free set of books for the school library from Rosen Publishing Company.

Katina Anagnostou will be recognized at the 2020 OELMA Conference.
text:
The Ohio Educational Library Media Association, Ohio’s preeminent professional association for highly effective school librarians and libraries, is pleased to announce that Katina Anagnostou, Library Media Specialist at Berea-Midpark Middle School is the recipient of the Rosen Publishing Ohio School Librarian of the Month Award.

The Rosen Publishing Ohio School Librarian of the Month recognizes one school librarian a month who designs, develops, and implements a collaborative lesson plan and/or programming that empowers student learning. This award spotlights the importance of both the school library community and librarian and the pivotal role each plays in transforming learning throughout students’ K-12 education.

Katina Anagnostou, as the recipient of this award, will have the opportunity to select and receive a free set of books for the school library from Rosen Publishing Company.

Katina Anagnostou will be recognized at the 2020 OELMA Conference.

post_text:
For the second time, Berea-Midpark High School has been recognized as a Cleveland Clinic Banner School for their work in the Cleveland Clinic Expressions Program. This program brings together science/health, math, literature, and the arts, and exposes students to real-world situations, while also allowing them to explore the depths of their creativity.

Berea-Midpark High School has won at least one award each year during the past fourteen years along with the only second Legacy Award Winner in CCEP history (Brianna Zahir '13). BMHS has also had a Best in Show winner, Emma Januszewski, this past year.

Berea-Midpark High School has won at least one award each year during the past fourteen years along with the only second Legacy Award Winner in CCEP history (Brianna Zahir '13). BMHS has also had a Best in Show winner, Emma Januszewski, this past year.

post_text:
SENIORS! Don’t miss the deadline! Be sure to take part in our PASS THE CAP CHALLENGE!

Here’s what to do:

Once you have your commencement gown, take a vertical video of yourself receiving your cap from your right side (pretend someone is handing it to you or actually have someone hand it to you). Place your cap on your head (smile, strike a pose, do a dance anything you’d like (school-appropriate!), then take your cap off and pass it to your left.

The videos will be mashed together to create the illusion that we are all passing our caps to each other, to show that we are all in this together. #BeATitanTOGETHER

Please upload your video by going to:
https://bit.ly/capchallenge2020

All videos must be uploaded by May 17

Once you have your commencement gown, take a vertical video of yourself receiving your cap from your right side (pretend someone is handing it to you or actually have someone hand it to you). Place your cap on your head (smile, strike a pose, do a dance anything you’d like (school-appropriate!), then take your cap off and pass it to your left.

The videos will be mashed together to create the illusion that we are all passing our caps to each other, to show that we are all in this together. #BeATitanTOGETHER

Please upload your video by going to:
https://bit.ly/capchallenge2020

All videos must be uploaded by May 17

post_text:
The Berea City School District has not made a definitive decision on where the Tree of Knowledge will be placed once it is removed from Berea-Midpark High School. BMHS is not scheduled to be demolished for several months. At no point did the District consider not saving the Tree of Knowledge when BMHS is demolished. The District is working with Panzica to get the necessary information about where the sculpture can go, who will be doing the restoration of the sculpture, and all costs involved. At this time, there are no assurances that can be given. Once the Board of Education gets all of the necessary information, they will make a decision on the sculpture and share that with the school community.

Photo credit: Lakehouse Photography
text:
The Berea City School District has not made a definitive decision on where the Tree of Knowledge will be placed once it is removed from Berea-Midpark High School. BMHS is not scheduled to be demolished for several months. At no point did the District consider not saving the Tree of Knowledge when BMHS is demolished. The District is working with Panzica to get the necessary information about where the sculpture can go, who will be doing the restoration of the sculpture, and all costs involved. At this time, there are no assurances that can be given. Once the Board of Education gets all of the necessary information, they will make a decision on the sculpture and share that with the school community.

Photo credit: Lakehouse Photography

shared_text:
Ohio Department of Education
April 15 at 11:16 PM ·

Join us to recognize and celebrate the strength and resilience of military-connected children and families! ✨🇺🇸✨

This month we honor Ohio's 35,000 military children for the sacrifices they make while members of their family serve in our nation's Armed Forces.

Frequent moves and family separations brought about by deployments can present many challenges for these students. Because of their ability to handle these life-changing events, military children are an inspiration and source of pride to our communities, state and the nation!

Learn more about Ohio’s supports for military families: http://education.ohio.gov/Topics/Other-Resources/Ohio-Network-for-Military-Families-and-Veterans/Supporting-Ohio-s-Military-Families

#MonthOfTheMilitaryChild #PurpleUp #OhioEd

Ohio Department of Veterans Services
April 6 at 4:22 PM ·

If you would like to write a letter or get a message to any of the more than 700 Ohio Veterans living inside our two Ohio Veterans Homes during this challenging time, here are a few options:

You can send a card or letter to either ...

Veteran
2003 Veterans Boulevard
Georgetown, Ohio 45121

Veteran
3416 Columbus Avenue
Sandusky, Ohio 44870

Or you can e-mail regards to G-Activities@dvs.ohio.gov

Each home’s activities department is taking care of distributing letters to the veterans.

We also have a “drop off” table outside each home if you want to drop off a message, donation or care package.

#InThisTogetherOhio

post_text:
The Berea Elks Lodge #1815 announced this year's Elks Americanism Essay local winners! This year's theme was "What Does Freedom of Speech Mean to Me?" A committee of 12 Elk members selected these winning essays from a total of 755 submitted.

5th & 6th grade division winners:
Lacey Millhoane - 6th grade, Mrs. Slovick
Anna Cavanaugh - 6th grade, Mrs. Slovick
Mackenzie Roth - 6th grade, Mr. Pearl

7th & 8th grade division winners:
Katherine Errington - 7th grade, Mr. Trubiano

These local winners moved onto the district level. At the district level, Lacey Millhoane placed 3rd and Katherine Errington placed 1st in their respective divisions. Both will be moving on to the State contest. They will now compete with the winners of the five other Ohio Districts to move on to the national contest. State winners will be announced sometime in April.

Congratulations to these students, their families, and teachers!
text:
The Berea Elks Lodge #1815 announced this year's Elks Americanism Essay local winners! This year's theme was "What Does Freedom of Speech Mean to Me?" A committee of 12 Elk members selected these winning essays from a total of 755 submitted.

5th & 6th grade division winners:
Lacey Millhoane - 6th grade, Mrs. Slovick
Anna Cavanaugh - 6th grade, Mrs. Slovick
Mackenzie Roth - 6th grade, Mr. Pearl

7th & 8th grade division winners:
Katherine Errington - 7th grade, Mr. Trubiano

These local winners moved onto the district level. At the district level, Lacey Millhoane placed 3rd and Katherine Errington placed 1st in their respective divisions. Both will be moving on to the State contest. They will now compete with the winners of the five other Ohio Districts to move on to the national contest. State winners will be announced sometime in April.

Congratulations to these students, their families, and teachers!

shared_text:
Berea Chamber of Commerce
March 25 at 3:23 AM ·

The Berea Chamber of Commerce is launching a project called Cards of Care where we will be collecting cards, pictures and notes for residents of our Berea area nursing homes while they are in isolation due to the COVID-19 outbreak.

Thank you to our partners at Broad View Eye Center and U.S. Bank Berea for serving as collection sites for the cards.

This is a great project for kids while schools are closed or for any community members that would like to contribute an encouraging note.

We will continue to collect cards and materials as long as the state mandate preventing visitors at nursing facilities is in place. We are also working with the facilities to follow CDC guidelines to ensure these materials can be delivered and distributed safely.

Please help us bring a smile to the residents of our Berea area nursing facilities!
text:
Berea Chamber of Commerce
March 25 at 3:23 AM ·

The Berea Chamber of Commerce is launching a project called Cards of Care where we will be collecting cards, pictures and notes for residents of our Berea area nursing homes while they are in isolation due to the COVID-19 outbreak.

Thank you to our partners at Broad View Eye Center and U.S. Bank Berea for serving as collection sites for the cards.

This is a great project for kids while schools are closed or for any community members that would like to contribute an encouraging note.

We will continue to collect cards and materials as long as the state mandate preventing visitors at nursing facilities is in place. We are also working with the facilities to follow CDC guidelines to ensure these materials can be delivered and distributed safely.

Please help us bring a smile to the residents of our Berea area nursing facilities!

shared_text:
The College Board
March 16 at 6:26 PM ·

The College Board is developing tools to mitigate the impact of school closures on students in the Advanced Placement Program. All AP students and teachers will be able to draw on the free online resources that were provided to every AP classroom this fall. Additional resources will be made easily accessible to AP students and teachers through mobile phones and other devices. These include free online AP lessons and review sessions from some of the top AP teachers in the country.

The AP program is finalizing streamlined AP exam options that would allow students to test at home, depending on the situation in May. We’re working to give every AP student the opportunity to claim the credit they’ve earned. The AP Program will communicate the details of these additional solutions to educators and students by March 20.

The College Board’s focus will remain on student safety and ensuring all students have the tools they need to work, and opportunities to receive the credit they have earned, during this challenging time.

More details: http://spr.ly/61861srPq.
